Still, there were aspects that were profoundly disturbing to
persons who have seen scores of demonstrations over the years. And
I believe these aspects make the thing worth reporting.
I was having my shoes shined on the sidewalk of the Corao when
the first storm broke on Home on the morning of November 6. I call
it a storm because it sounded exactly like one; a great, gathering
thunderstorm, hurtling down on you in the teeth of a mighty wind.
Before I had time to ask the bootblack what was happening the
storm was upon us: a storm of shouting, screaming, sometimes chanting
students — most of them 15 and 16-year olds from the media schools;
thousands of them, completely Jamming the Carso and the sidewalks,
paralyzing traffic on one of Home's busiest streets; stopping only
long enough to chalk on walla, buildings, buses and streetcars insults
about iiarshal Tito and Gen. Sir John Winterton, the British military
commander in Trieste; epithets about Anthony Eden and the U. 3. A.;
demands for the return to Italy not only of Trieste but of the whole
Dalmatian coast.
They would stop and scribble frantically with chalk, and then
they would rush on, pell me11 and halter skelter, behind their leaders
who added a shrill not® to the great wave of sound by blowing wantx
constantly and furiously on police whistles.
They threatened to turn over a truck whose driver had edged out
into the middle of the Corao, hoping to get across ahead of them. They
screamed insults at policemen and bus drivers and pedestrians who got
in their way. Still they came on — and one wondered how many school
children of that age Home had.
